section-block.rac_essential-question: What makes us who we are?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written and illustrated by Todd Parr
section-block.rac_book_summary: Let’s see the things that make us who we are. We can find ways we are just like each other and some ways that we are different. But remember, it is wonderful to be the amazing child you are!

section-block.rac_body-text: Gather children to welcome them. Tell them they will be reading wonderful books, learning our letters, playing and pretending. Invite children to say their names.
Invite children to join in as you sing “The Alphabet Song.” Sing the song slowly through once or twice. Then ask children to name one letter from the song they really like.
Introduce a new word that will be helpful when talking about feelings.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Be Who You Are, written by Todd Parr. He also drew the pictures for this book.
Meet Pablo the Parrot. He will read with us. He loves to read informational texts about real people and things. Today we will read about children like you.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we read. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do children like to do?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose two or three children to share their responses.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you see on the cover of this book? Let’s find out what these children like to do.
One boy likes to play the guitar and sing. The other boy likes to pretend he is a superhero. What do you like to pretend to be?
The boy says “Hola” and the dog says “Hello.” “Hola” is “Hello” in Spanish. Let’s pretend a friend just walked in. Let’s all say, “Hello.” And let’s all say, “Hola.”
What do these children like to do when they hear music? Let’s dance with our hands! When you dance, how do you feel? (MB)
What does this girl like to do? Raise your hands and show how you would catch a ball.
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What do children like to do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Write and read aloud a short sentence about one of the things children in the book like to do, as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do children do when you hear music?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Creating a welcoming environment can help children transition from the home to preK. Keep mementos of home in the spaces designated for each child. Specific examples may include a favorite teddy bear, a family picture, or a drawing the child did. These make the space more like home for the child.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Talk About Feelings
section-block.rac_body-text: Begin a discussion about feelings by saying, “People have lots of feelings.” Then share a time when you were happy and tell why you felt that way. Encourage children to tell about a time they were happy and what made them feel that way.
Introduce new words to help children talk about feelings.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread some of the pages from Be Who You Are by Todd Parr. We will talk about feelings.
Meet Clifford. Who has seen Clifford before? Was he in a book? Was he on TV? Clifford likes to talk about his feelings. Right now he is happy because he likes to read with us.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to share their responses.
Read aloud the book and the Day 2 prompts.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at the boy playing the guitar and singing. Let’s pretend to play guitar and sing. How do you feel? (MB)
These children have faces of all different colors. How can you tell they are all happy? (MB)
This boy has tears falling from his eyes. Who is he sharing his sad feelings with? Who do you like to share your feelings with? (MB)
Which dog is sad? Which dog is proud? Sometimes you can tell how someone feels by the look on her face. Can you show me a happy face? A mad face? A sad face? A proud face? (MB)
The little mouse does not want the cat to come in, so he says “NO!” in a big voice. We can use our words to tell others how we feel. Say, “NO!” in a big voice. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to stand in a circle and play a happy game. Tell children to follow along and join in doing things that make us happy. Say, “Jumping makes me happy, so let’s jump, jump, jump.” Then say: “Hopping makes me happy, so let’s hop, hop, hop.” Continue with dancing, clapping, and twisting.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how they feel when they do a favorite activity.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Remember that children may not have the words to say what they’re feeling. Point out an emotion a child is showing, such as feeling proud, and ask questions about how and why they’re feeling that way. Giving them words to describe the feeling can help them with relationships and their own mental and emotional health.

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk about being like someone else. Give examples such as,“I like purple; clap if you’re like me,” “I like fruit; clap if you’re like me,” and “I like to draw; clap if you’re like me.”
Invite children to join in as you sing “The Alphabet Song.” Then take a walk around the room and have children point out where they see letters. Read any words to them.
Introduce a new word that will help children talk about their feelings.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the book Be Who You Are by Todd Parr.
The book we will read is about things that make us who we are.Pablo loves to learn about children and the things they do that make them who they are.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How are you like the children in the book?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How do the people in your family say “Hello”?
Why does the little shark need tobe brave right now? When was a time when you were brave? (MB)
This boy wore his pants on his head while taking a bath. He feels very silly. What do you do when you feel silly? (MB)
These children play, discover, learn, and read. Give me a thumbs up if you are like the children who like to play. Do you like to discover? Learn? Read?

Sometimes we are different from our friends. These children eat tacos, noodles, and pizza. Which of these foods do you like to eat? How are the foods you like to eat different from what these children like to eat?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How are you like the children in the book?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I like to be silly like the boy in the bath.
I like tacos like the boy and girl.
I play baseball like the girl.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to describe and write about ways children are like each other.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you like to be silly?
When do you like to be silly?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: As children develop and experience more social interactions, they begin to notice differences between people-in gender, race, traditions, language, and culture. Research shows that teaching children to respect and appreciate differences early on in their development is key to preventing future bias and intolerance.

section-block.rac_body-text: Engage children by asking them to think about what they like about preK. Encourage children to share their thoughts about what is fun to do at preK.
Ask children to show you a happy face. Then play the PreK On My Way theme music and encourage them to move about the room doing a happy dance.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to look at a poster called I like to . . . On the poster are pictures that go with the poem I will read to you.
section.rac_body-text: Use the Pablo Stick Puppet.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: You remember Pablo. He loves to look at posters with pictures of children just like you.
Be Who You Are and I like to . . . tell about things that make us who we are. Let’s listen for connections between them.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Be Who You Are book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s Concept Question: What makes us who we are?
section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to All About Me
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart. Then use these prompts to read and discuss the poster together.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to take turns responding.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The title of this poster is “I like to . . .” Who can point to the words? Who can point to the pictures?
Point to the boy with the book. The boy says, “I like to read a book.” I think the boy is reading about dinosaurs. What do you think he is reading about?
Point to the girl with the red ball. The girl says, “I like to play catch.” I’ll pretend to throw a ball and you catch it.
Point to the girl who is drawing with a crayon. The girl says, “I like to make a square.” Show me how she could draw a circle.

section.rac_body-text: Lead children in this variation of “Simon Says.” Call out directions that highlight things children like to do. For example: If you like to draw, Simon says, “Tap your nose.” If you like to ride a bike, Simon says, “Clap your hands.” If you like to play catch, Simon says, “Stand up.”
Provide a writing prompt to encourage children to write about something they like to do and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: For many learners, especially for multilingual learners, comprehension can be one of the most challenging reading skills to grasp. In Reading Comprehension Strategies for English Language Learners, the author suggests to (1) build background knowledge, (2) teach vocabulary explicitly, and (3) check comprehension frequently.

section-block.rac_body-text: Ask children to pretend that they haven’t ever met before. Invite them to take turns introducing themselves to their classmates and sharing what alphabet letters they like best. Model the activity by standing and introducing yourself: My name is [your name]. My favorite letters are Oo and Bb.
Introduce a new word that will help children talk about what they do.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Be Who You Are by Todd Parr.
Pablo the Parrot loves reading this informational text. He listens and looks at the pictures.
This week, we read about things children do. As we read the book one more time, think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are some things you can do?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: One boy is pretending to be a superhero. What do you like to be when you pretend with friends?
What are these children doing? Stand up and show how you can dance. Dance until I say stop.
These children play. They read. They discover new things about butterflies. They use a globe to learn about the world. What do you want to learn about in preK?

Just like a real person, this dog shows us his feelings. We can use our faces to show our feelings. Can you show me a very silly face? A mad face? A happy face? A sad face? A scared face? A proud face? (MB)
Look at the word mad. What letters do you see in the word mad?
These children are full of energy. Show your energy. Hop up and down until I say stop.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What are some things you can do?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about something they can do.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What things can we do with our friends in preK?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Healthy social-emotional development helps children forge new friendships with peers and adults. To foster social-emotional growth, consider using emotion words and encouraging children to do the same, especially when working through conflicts.
